question.title: Import Kotlin class with public in the package name in a Java project
question.body:
I'm trying to integrate my legacy app (in Java) with a library from a new partner (made with Kotlin). The development went smooth until the refund part, the thing is I can't import some classes from the library, in Android Studio it shows to me in both class finder or suggestion, but when I try to import even with * I get unreferenced class.

I noticed all the classes I'm having this problem are in a public folder in the library. My assumption is that since public is a reserved word, the project is getting lost:

com.zoop.pos.plugin.public.requestBuilder.VoidTransactionResponse
com.zoop.pos.plugin.public.requestBuilder.MenuOptions
com.zoop.pos.plugin.public.requestBuilder.LastReceiptResponse
com.zoop.pos.plugin.public.requestBuilder.PixPaymentResponse

Is there any way to use this class without requiring any development from the other company?

answers.body:
As @k314159 said JLS forbids reserved words from being part of a package name, making it impossible to import those classes in Java.

Note: The use of Reflection or a Kotlin Wrapper might work, further tests required

question_comments.body: @aled tried it today, the import fails as well

As you suspected, the JLS forbids reserved words from being part of a package name. The fact that the author of this library has chosen to use "public" might be because they specifically want to make it impossible to call their classes from Java. If that's not the case, they should be alerted to the fact that their library cannot be called from Java, and they should change their package name. If they won't, you could try writing a Kotlin wrapper as Khar Varsha suggested in an answer which Dalija Prasnikar later deleted for some unknown reason.
Did you try creating a library with a package that has public to test your hypothesis?
